Email traffic exhibiting characteristics.Action: Analyze Zeek smtp.log and dns.log for incoming messages with SPF/DKIM failures or header anomalies indicative of spoofing. Identify incoming email campaigns where a single external sender address or domain attempts to send messages to a statistically significant number of internal recipients (using frequency analysis).

Email messages containing suspicious req.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek conn.log; Zeek dns.log
Email messages containing suspicious req.Action: Monitor Zeek http.log, conn.log, and dns.log for connections originating from internal users shortly after receiving emails. Extract URLs from email logs (if available, otherwise infer from network connections) and perform automated lookups against threat intelligence feeds and URL categorization services. Use correlation analysis to link recipients of suspicious emails to subsequent network activity (e.g., connections to flagged IPs/domains).

High volume of outbound email replies or.Action: Monitor Zeek smtp.log for outbound emails from internal users to external domains/addresses not in a baseline of frequent contacts. Use Zeek conn.log to identify related outbound connections. Calculate the frequency and volume of outbound communications for internal users to rare or new external destinations. Flag users with a statistically significant increase in outbound emails/connections to unusual external contacts, especially if correlated with receiving emails flagged as suspicious.

Process execution or network connections.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 5156; Zeek http.log; Zeek conn.log
Process execution or network connections.Action: Correlate Windows Event ID 4688 (process creation) and 5156 (outbound network connections) on endpoints/servers. Identify processes spawned shortly after a user (based on successful logon Event ID 4624 correlation or known email recipients) interacts with email content (e.g., browser child processes, script hosts). Correlate these processes/connections with Zeek logs (http.log, conn.log) to identify connections to known malicious IPs/domains or destinations statistically rare for the user/organization (using frequency analysis or entropy measures).
